text: The words of the spokesman, the son of David and the king in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Absolutely pointless!” says the spokesman. “Absolutely pointless! Everything is pointless.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What do people gain from all their hard work under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Generations come, and generations go,
but the earth lasts forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun rises, and the sun sets,
and then it rushes back to the place where it will rise again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wind blows toward the south and shifts toward the north.
Round and round it blows. It blows in a full circle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All streams flow into the sea, but the sea is never full.
The water goes back to the place where the streams began
in order to start flowing again.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these sayings are worn-out phrases. They are more than anyone can express, comprehend, or understand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever has happened before will happen again. Whatever has been done before will be done again. There is nothing new under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Can you say that anything is new? It has already been here long before us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nothing from the past is remembered. Even in the future, nothing will be remembered by those who come after us.
speaker: Narrator

text: I, the spokesman, have been king of Israel in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With all my heart I used wisdom to study and explore everything done under heaven.
Mortals are weighed down with a terrible burden that God has placed on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen everything that is done under the sun. Look at it! It’s all pointless. It’s like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one can straighten what is bent.
No one can count what is not there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought to myself, “I have grown wiser than anyone who has ruled Jerusalem before me. I’ve had a lot of experience with wisdom and knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I’ve used my mind to understand wisdom and knowledge as well as madness and stupidity. Now I know that this is like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With a lot of wisdom comes a lot of heartache.
The greater your knowledge, the greater your pain.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought to myself, “Now I want to experiment with pleasure and enjoy myself.” But even this was pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought, “Laughter doesn’t make any sense. What does pleasure accomplish?”
speaker: Narrator

text: I explored ways to make myself feel better by drinking wine. I also explored ways to do some foolish things. During all that time, wisdom continued to control my mind. I was able to determine whether this was good for mortals to do during their brief lives under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I accomplished some great things:
I built houses for myself.
I planted vineyards for myself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I made gardens and parks for myself.
I planted every kind of fruit tree in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I made pools to water the forest of growing trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I bought male and female slaves.
In addition, slaves were born in my household.
I owned more herds and flocks
than anyone in Jerusalem before me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also gathered silver and gold for myself.
I gathered the treasures of kings and provinces.
I provided myself with male and female singers
and the pleasures men have with one concubine  after another.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I grew richer than anyone in Jerusalem before me. Yet, my wisdom remained with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: If something appealed to me, I did it. I allowed myself to have any pleasure I wanted, since I found pleasure in my work. This was my reward for all my hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when I turned to look at all that I had accomplished and all the hard work I had put into it, I saw that it was all pointless. It was like trying to catch the wind. I gained nothing from any of my accomplishments under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I turned my attention to experience wisdom, madness, and foolishness. For instance, what can the man who replaces the king do? Only what has already been done.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I saw that wisdom has an advantage over foolishness as light has an advantage over darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise person uses the eyes in his head, but a fool walks in the dark. But I have also come to realize that the same destiny waits for both of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought to myself, “If the destiny that waits for the fool waits for me as well, then what is the advantage in being wise?” So I thought that even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither the wise person nor the fool will be remembered for long, since both will be forgotten in the days to come. Both the wise person and the fool will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I came to hate life because everything done under the sun seemed wrong to me. Everything was pointless. It was like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: I came to hate everything for which I had worked so hard under the sun, because I will have to leave it to the person who replaces me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who knows whether that person will be wise or foolish? He will still have control over everything under the sun for which I worked so hard and used my wisdom. Even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I fell into despair over everything for which I had worked so hard under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is someone who had worked hard with wisdom, knowledge, and skill. Yet, he must turn over his estate to someone else, who didn’t work for it. Even this is pointless and a terrible tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: What do people get from all of their hard work and struggles under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text: Their entire life is filled with pain, and their work is unbearable. Even at night their minds don’t rest. Even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is nothing better for people to do than to eat, drink, and find satisfaction in their work. I saw that even this comes from the hand of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who can eat or enjoy themselves without God?
speaker: Narrator

text: God gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy to anyone who pleases him. But to the person who continues to sin, he gives the job of gathering and collecting wealth. The sinner must turn his wealth over to the person who pleases God. Even this is pointless. It’s like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything has its own time, and there is a specific time for every activity under heaven:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to be born and
a time to die,
a time to plant and
a time to pull out what was planted,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to kill and
a time to heal,
a time to tear down and
a time to build up,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to cry and
a time to laugh,
a time to mourn and
a time to dance,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to scatter stones and
a time to gather them,
a time to hug and
a time to stop hugging,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to start looking and
a time to stop looking,
a time to keep and
a time to throw away,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to tear apart and
a time to sew together,
a time to keep quiet and
a time to speak out,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a time to love and
a time to hate,
a time for war and
a time for peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: What do working people gain from their hard labor?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen mortals weighed down with a burden that God has placed on them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is beautiful how God has done everything at the right time. He has put a sense of eternity in people’s minds. Yet, mortals still can’t grasp what God is doing from the beginning to the end of time.
speaker: Narrator

text: I realize that there’s nothing better for them to do than to be cheerful and enjoy what is good in their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a gift from God to be able to eat and drink and experience the good that comes from every kind of hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: I realize that whatever God does will last forever. Nothing can be added to it, and nothing can be taken away from it. God does this so that people will fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever has happened in the past is present now. Whatever is going to happen in the future has already happened in the past. God will call the past to account.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I saw something else under the sun:
There is wickedness where justice should be found.
There is wickedness where righteousness should be found.
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought to myself, “God will judge righteous people as well as wicked people, because there is a specific time for every activity and every work that is done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I thought to myself, “God is going to test humans in order to show them that they are like animals.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Humans and animals have the same destiny. One dies just like the other. All of them have the same breath of life. Humans have no advantage over animals. All of life is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: All life goes to the same place. All life comes from the ground, and all of it goes back to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who knows whether a human spirit goes upward or whether an animal spirit goes downward to the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw that there’s nothing better for people to do than to enjoy their work because that is their lot in life. Who will allow them to see what will happen after them?
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, I turned to look at all the acts of oppression that make people suffer under the sun. Look at the tears of those who suffer! No one can comfort them. Their oppressors have all the power. No one can comfort those who suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text: I congratulate the dead, who have already died, rather than the living, who still have to carry on.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who hasn’t been born yet is better off than both of them. He hasn’t seen the evil that is done under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw that all hard work and skillful effort come from rivalry. Even this is pointless. It’s like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool folds his hands and wastes away.
speaker: Narrator

text: One handful of peace and quiet is better than two handfuls of hard work and of trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next, I turned to look at something pointless under the sun:
speaker: Narrator

text: There are people who are all alone. They have no children or other family members. So there is no end to all the hard work they have to do. Their eyes are never satisfied with riches. But they never ask themselves why they are working so hard and depriving themselves of good things. Even this is pointless and a terrible tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two people are better than one because together they have a good reward for their hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: If one falls, the other can help his friend get up. But how tragic it is for the one who is all alone when he falls. There is no one to help him get up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again, if two people lie down together, they can keep warm, but how can one person keep warm?
speaker: Narrator

text: Though one person may be overpowered by another, two people can resist one opponent. A triple-braided rope is not easily broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man who is poor and wise is better than an old, foolish king who won’t take advice any longer.
speaker: Narrator

text: A young man came out of prison to rule as king, even though he had been born in poverty in that same kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw all living people moving about under the sun. They sided with the second young man, the king’s successor.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no end to all those people, everyone whom he led. But those who will come later will not be happy with the successor. Even this is pointless. It’s like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Watch your step when you go to the house of God. It is better to go there and listen than to bring the sacrifices fools bring. Fools are unaware that they are doing something evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be in a hurry to talk. Don’t be eager to speak in the presence of God. Since God is in heaven and you are on earth, limit the number of your words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Daydreaming comes when there are too many worries.
Careless speaking comes when there are too many words.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you make a promise to God, don’t be slow to keep it because God doesn’t like fools. Keep your promise.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better not to make a promise than to make one and not keep it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t let your mouth talk you into committing a sin. Don’t say in the presence of a temple messenger, “My promise was a mistake!” Why should God become angry at your excuse and destroy what you’ve accomplished?
speaker: Narrator

text: In spite of many daydreams, pointless actions, and empty words, you should still fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be surprised if you see poor people being oppressed, denied justice, or denied their rights in any district. One authority is watching over another, and they both have authorities watching over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet, a king is an advantage for a country with cultivated fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever loves money will never be satisfied with money. Whoever loves wealth will never be satisfied with more income. Even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the number of goods increase, so do the number of people who consume them. What do owners gain from all their goods except the opportunity to look at them?
speaker: Narrator

text: The sleep of working people is sweet, whether they eat a little or a lot. But the full stomachs that rich people have will not allow them to sleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a painful tragedy that I have seen under the sun: Riches lead to the downfall of those who hoard them.
speaker: Narrator

text: These hoarded riches were then lost in bad business deals. The owners had children, but now they have nothing to give them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came from their mother’s womb naked. They will leave as naked as they came. They won’t even be able to take a handful of their earnings with them from all their hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: This also is a painful tragedy: They leave exactly as they came. What advantage do they gain from working so hard for the wind?
speaker: Narrator

text: They spend their entire lives in darkness, in constant frustration, sickness, and resentment.
speaker: Narrator

text: At last I have seen what is good and beautiful: It is to eat and drink and to enjoy the good in all our hard work under the sun during the brief lives God gives us. That is our lot in life.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a gift from God when God gives some people wealth and possessions, the power to enjoy them, the ability to accept their lot in life, and the ability to rejoice in their own hard work.
speaker: Narrator

text: These people won’t give much thought to their brief lives because God keeps them occupied with the joy in their hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a tragedy that I have seen under the sun. It is a terrible one for mortals.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gives one person riches, wealth, and honor so that he doesn’t lack anything he wants. Yet, God doesn’t give him the power to enjoy any of them. Instead, a stranger enjoys them. This is pointless and is a painful tragedy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Suppose a rich person wasn’t satisfied with good things while he was alive and didn’t even get an honorable burial after he died. Suppose he had a hundred children and lived for many years. No matter how long he would have lived, it still would have been better for him to have been born dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: A stillborn baby arrives in a pointless birth and goes out into the darkness. The darkness then hides its name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though it has never seen the sun or known anything, the baby finds more rest than the rich person.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if the rich person lives two thousand years without experiencing anything good—don’t we all go to the same place?
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that people work so hard for goes into their mouths, but their appetite is never satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: What advantage does a wise person have over a fool? What advantage does a poor person have in knowing how to face life?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to look at what is in front of you than to go looking for what you want. Even this is pointless. It’s like trying to catch the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever has happened in the past already has a name. Mortals are already known for what they are. Mortals cannot argue with the one who is stronger than they.
speaker: Narrator

text: The more words there are, the more pointless they become. What advantage do mortals gain from this?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who knows what may be good for mortals while they are alive, during the brief, pointless days they live? Mortals pass by like a shadow. Who will tell them about their future under the sun?
speaker: Narrator

text: A good name is better than expensive perfume, and the day you die is better than the day you’re born.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to go to a funeral than to a banquet because that is where everyone will end up. Everyone who is alive should take this to heart!
speaker: Narrator

text: Sorrow is better than laughter because, in spite of a sad face, the heart can be joyful.
speaker: Narrator

text: The minds of wise people think about funerals, but the minds of fools think about banquets.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is better to listen to wise people who reprimand you than to fools who sing your praises.
speaker: Narrator

text: The laughter of a fool is like the crackling of thorns burning under a pot. Even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oppression can turn a wise person into a fool, and a bribe can corrupt the mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: The end of something is better than its beginning. It is better to be patient than arrogant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be quick to get angry, because anger is typical of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t ask, “Why were things better in the old days than they are now?” It isn’t wisdom that leads you to ask this!
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is as good as an inheritance. It is an advantage to everyone who sees the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom protects us just as money protects us, but the advantage of wisdom is that it gives life to those who have it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Consider what God has done! Who can straighten what God has bent?
speaker: Narrator

text: When times are good, be happy. But when times are bad, consider this: God has made the one time as well as the other so that mortals cannot predict their future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen it all in my pointless life:
Righteous people die in spite of being righteous.
Wicked people go on living in spite of being wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be too virtuous, and don’t be too wise. Why make yourself miserable?
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be too wicked, and don’t be a fool. Why should you die before your time is up?
speaker: Narrator

text: It’s good to hold on to the one and not let go of the other, because the one who fears God will be able to avoid both extremes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom will help a wise person more than ten rulers can help a city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Certainly, there is no one so righteous on earth that he always does what is good and never sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t take everything that people say to heart, or you may hear your own servant cursing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your conscience knows that you have cursed others many times.
speaker: Narrator

text: I used wisdom to test all of this. I said, “I want to be wise, but it is out of my reach.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever wisdom may be, it is out of reach. It is deep, very deep. Who can find out what it is?
speaker: Narrator

text: I turned my attention to study, to explore, and to seek out wisdom and the reason for things. I learned that wickedness is stupid and foolishness is madness.
speaker: Narrator

text: I find that a woman whose thoughts are like traps and snares is more bitter than death itself. Even her hands are like chains. Whoever pleases God will escape her, but she will catch whoever continues to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spokesman said, “This is what I’ve found: I added one thing to another in order to find a reason for things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am still seeking a reason for things, but have not found any. I found one man out of a thousand who had it, but out of all these I didn’t find one woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have found only this: God made people decent, but they looked for many ways to avoid being decent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is really wise? Who knows how to explain things? Wisdom makes one’s face shine, and it changes one’s grim look.
speaker: Narrator

text: I advise you to obey the king’s commands because of the oath you took in God’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t be in a hurry to leave the king’s service. Don’t take part in something evil, because he can do whatever he pleases.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since a king’s word has such power, no one can ask him what he is doing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever obeys his commands will avoid trouble. The mind of a wise person will know the right time and the right way to act.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a right time and a right way to act in every situation. Yet, a terrible human tragedy hangs over people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They don’t know what the future will bring. So who can tell them how things will turn out?
speaker: Narrator

text: No one has the power to prevent the spirit  of life from leaving. No one has control over the day of his own death. There is no way to avoid the war against death. Wickedness will not save wicked people from dying.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen all of this, and I have carefully considered all that is done under the sun whenever one person has authority to hurt others.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I saw wicked people given an honorable burial. They used to go in and out of the holy place. They were praised in the city for doing such things. Even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a sentence against a crime isn’t carried out quickly, people are encouraged to commit crimes.
speaker: Narrator

text: A sinner may commit a hundred crimes and yet live a long life. Still, I know with certainty that it will go well for those who fear God, because they fear him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it will not go well for the wicked. They will not live any longer. Their lives are like shadows, because they don’t fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is something being done on earth that is pointless. Righteous people suffer for what the wicked do, and wicked people get what the righteous deserve. I say that even this is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I recommend the enjoyment of life. People have nothing better to do under the sun than to eat, drink, and enjoy themselves. This joy will stay with them while they work hard during their brief lives which God has given them under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I carefully considered how to study wisdom and how to look at the work that is done on earth (even going without sleep day and night),
speaker: Narrator

text: then I saw everything that God has done. No one is able to grasp the work that is done under the sun. However hard a person may search for it, he will not find its meaning. Even though a wise person claims to know, he is not able to grasp it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, I have carefully thought about all this, and I explain it in this way: Righteous people and wise people, along with their accomplishments, are in God’s hands. No one knows whether there will be love or hatred.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything turns out the same way for everyone. All people will share the same destiny, whether they are righteous, wicked, or good, clean or unclean, whether they offer sacrifices or don’t offer sacrifices. Good people are treated like sinners. People who take oaths are treated like those who are afraid to take oaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the tragedy of everything that happens under the sun: Everyone shares the same destiny. Moreover, the hearts of mortals are full of evil. Madness is in their hearts while they are still alive. After that, they join the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all who are among the living have hope, because a living dog is better than a dead lion.
speaker: Narrator

text: The living know that they will die, but the dead don’t know anything. There is no more reward for the dead when the memory of them has faded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their love, their hate, and their passions have already vanished. They will never again take part in anything that happens under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go, enjoy eating your food, and drink your wine cheerfully, because God has already accepted what you’ve done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Always wear clean clothes, and never go without lotion on your head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enjoy life with your wife, whom you love, during all your brief, pointless life. God has given you your pointless life under the sun. This is your lot in life and what you get for the hard work that you do under the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever presents itself for you to do, do it with all your might, because there is no work, planning, knowledge, or skill in the grave where you’re going.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw something else under the sun. The race isn’t won by fast runners, or the battle by heroes. Wise people don’t necessarily have food. Intelligent people don’t necessarily have riches, and skilled people don’t necessarily receive special treatment. But time and unpredictable events overtake all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one knows when his time will come. Like fish that are caught in a cruel net or birds caught in a snare, humans are trapped by a disaster when it suddenly strikes them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also have seen this example of wisdom under the sun, and it made a deep impression on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a small town with a few soldiers in it, and a powerful king came to attack it. He surrounded it and blockaded it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A poor, wise person was found in that town. He saved the town using his wisdom. But no one remembered that poor person.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said, “Wisdom is better than strength,” even though that poor person’s wisdom was despised, and no one listened to what he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: One should pay more attention to calm words from wise people than shouting from a ruler of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner can destroy much that is good.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dead flies will make a bottle of perfume stink, and then it is spoiled. A little foolishness outweighs wisdom and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise person’s heart leads the right way. The heart of a fool leads the wrong way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when a fool goes walking, he has no sense and shows everyone else that he’s a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a ruler becomes angry with you, don’t resign your position. If you remain calm, you can make up for serious offenses.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a tragedy that I’ve seen under the sun, an error often made by rulers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foolish people are often given high positions, and rich people are left to fill lower positions.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have seen slaves sitting on horses and influential people going on foot like slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever digs a pit may fall into it. Whoever breaks through a stone wall may be bitten by a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever works in a stone quarry may get hurt. Whoever splits wood may be injured.
speaker: Narrator

text: If an ax is blunt and the edge isn’t sharpened, then one has to use more strength. But wisdom prepares the way for success.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a snake bites before it has been charmed, then there is no advantage in being a snake charmer.
speaker: Narrator

text: A wise person’s words win favors, but a fool’s lips are self-destructive.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fool starts out by talking foolishness and ends up saying crazy things that are dangerous.
speaker: Narrator

text: He never stops talking. No one knows what the future will bring, or what will happen after death. Who can say!
speaker: Narrator

text: Fools wear themselves out with hard work, because they don’t even know the way to town.
speaker: Narrator

text: How horrible it will be for any country where the king used to be a servant and where the high officials throw parties in the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: A country is blessed when the king is from a noble family and when the high officials eat at the right time in order to get strength and not to get drunk.
speaker: Narrator

text: A roof sags because of laziness. A house leaks because of idle hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: A meal is made for laughter, and wine makes life pleasant, but money is the answer for everything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t curse the king even in your thoughts, and don’t curse rich people even in your bedroom. A bird may carry your words, or some winged creature may repeat what you say.
speaker: Narrator

text: Throw your bread on the surface of the water, because you will find it again after many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Divide what you have into seven parts, or even into eight, because you don’t know what disaster may happen on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the clouds are full of rain, they will let it pour down on the earth. If a tree falls north or south, the tree will remain where it fell.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever watches the wind will never plant. Whoever looks at the clouds will never harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as you don’t know how the breath of life enters the limbs of a child within its mother’s womb, you also don’t understand how God, who made everything, works.
speaker: Narrator

text: Plant your seed in the morning, and don’t let your hands rest until evening. You don’t know whether this field or that field will be profitable or whether both of them will turn out equally well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Light is sweet, and it is good for one’s eyes to see the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though people may live for many years, they should enjoy every one of them. But they should also remember there will be many dark days. Everything that is coming is pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text: You young people should enjoy yourselves while you’re young. You should let your hearts make you happy when you’re young. Follow wherever your heart leads you and whatever your eyes see. But realize that God will make you give an account for all these things when he judges everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get rid of what troubles you or wears down your body, because childhood and youth are pointless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator when you are young,
before the days of trouble come
and the years catch up with you.
They will make you say,
“I have found no pleasure in them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator before the sun, the light, the moon,
and the stars turn dark, and the clouds come back with rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator when those who guard the house tremble,
strong men are stooped over,
the women at the mill stop grinding
because there are so few of them,
and those who look out of the windows
see a dim light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator when the doors to the street are closed,
the sound of the mill is muffled,
you are startled at the sound of a bird,
and those who sing songs become quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator when someone is afraid of heights
and of dangers along the road,
the almond tree blossoms,
the grasshopper drags itself along,
and the caper bush has no fruit.
Mortals go to their eternal rest, and mourners go out in the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your Creator before the silver cord is snapped,
the golden bowl is broken,
the pitcher is smashed near the spring,
and the water wheel is broken at the cistern.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the dust of mortals goes back to the ground as it was before,
and the breath of life goes back to God who gave it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Absolutely pointless!” says the spokesman. “Everything is pointless!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Besides being wise, the spokesman also taught the people what he knew. He very carefully thought about it, studied it, and arranged it in many proverbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The spokesman tried to find just the right words. He wrote the words of truth very carefully.
speaker: Narrator

text: Words from wise people are like spurs. Their collected sayings are like nails that have been driven in firmly. They come from one shepherd.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be warned, my children, against anything more than these. People never stop writing books. Too much studying will wear out your body.
speaker: Narrator

text: After having heard it all, this is the conclusion: Fear God, and keep his commands, because this applies to everyone.
speaker: Narrator

text: God will certainly judge everything that is done. This includes every secret thing, whether it is good or bad.
speaker: Narrator
